element_texts.text: went in behind or to the west of the Sundance Hills - struck there a very bitter alkaline creek & followed it down to where the trail crossed it - Had lunch - got out my shot gun in stacks again after giving directions as to how the Comd should go for at this point I left Curtin Trail. I went on to the north

a nice? camp. Though the water is some of the best - Com? made today about 21 miles - I must have made 35 - Fred struck by me remarkably vile but his "botty" is a little sore tonight - To bed earlyunclear satisfied high? - unclear progress & hopeful for tomorrow -

a nice camp, though the water is some of the best - Corn? made? today about 21 miles - I must have made 35 - Fred stuck by me remarkably well but his "botty" is a little sore tonight - To bed early - well satisfied with the days progress & hopeful for tomorrow -

rapid - There are a good many suckers in it but apparently no other fish - We have a most excellent camp, not much wood - but the grass & water are perfect. Sent Joe out this pm to look for tomorrow's route - He returned at dark, has found an excellent route & it is only 10 miles to "Spearfish" - so we are all elated - Bagged 1 spike or willow grouse

Travel in unclear wagons I have ever seen - by 11 AM we arrived at Red Water. (much to the discomfiture of Joe who had insisted it was 25 miles off) at a point scarcely a mile below where we would have struck it had we been able to go the way I wished - It is a large fine stream 30 feet wide by an average of 20 inches deep & very

Monday, Sepr 13 1875
Broke camp 6.30 am - Went ahead with King to find some lakes which were said to be ahead - In about 2 1/2 miles came upon a very lovely little lake, evidently fed by springs of pure water. It was surrounded by Tula Grass - The open water was about half a mile long by 200 yds wide - The swamp in the tula grass nearly doubled these dimensions

coming unclear also 1 mallard in this Creek before the Comd. came up - Had a 500 yd shot at an antelope - another equally long at a deer, both puny? & both misses - had hardly got the tents pitched before it commenced to rain - Had a good nap - Soli? in afternoon went out with Fred, & bagged 3 fine Suckers. There are a good  running? but they bit very badly. To bed rather late -

a mallard & 2 teal - & burst a cartridge in my gun - making that barrel useless - I then took to my rifle, & went off around the east side of Crow peaks after deer - went through a lovely hunting country for  miles beautiful oak woods without seeing a deer, or even a Track was cut off from my unclear hunt by a huge

There were numbers of ducks on it  - but after knocking down six, & bagging but one I gave up in disgust - The outlet of the lake is a small stream of beautiful water, which I did not taste - went on, Struck a small creek coming down from the west side of Crow peaks - It was a succession of unclear, on one of which we found a few ducks, then I bagged

for ducks, but found none as it is too swift for a duck to hold his grip in - It is a lovely stream hardly so large as Red Water, but from its great rapidity unclear more water. I had given unclear & Joe instructions about Camp, & my tent was pitched when I got in - We are in a lovely spot - The valley is a mile wide - nera the creek is timber - Oak ash Elm Box Elder & unclear a cotton unclear

canon coming down from Crow peaks, & had to come back towards the road -En route I bagged 2 grouses - ought to have got more - Overtook an ambulance in which lay a man who had fallen from his horse & badly hurt his arm - came down a tremendous hill to the valley of "Spear fish" found another pack of grouse & bagged 3 - went out the creek

Tuesday Sep 14, 1875 -
Didn't break camp, but slept peacefully until 7am - after breakfast Foot? & I went down the Creek to its junction with? unclear water, about 3? miles. The latter is much the largest creek - carrying at least one half more water - The two creeks when joined make a fine body of water

The water is splendid - clear pan & soft - We are now nearly on the plains level & the unclear is narrow - I was greatly disappointed that there is no game - but it is on the great N. & S. line of Indian travel, which accounts for this - Fine wood grass & water - Soil fine - unclear grapes to be found - unclear unclear. To bed late -

The evening was as lovely as could be desired by the most romantic young lovers a splendid full moon & balmy atmosphere - The country is very bare of game of any kind - I saw today but 3 ducks 2 of which I bagged - not another shootable thing. Except a rattlesnake & I bagged him with a fishing pole - we fished for a long time on the main stream below the

This stream is the best in the Hills for a Mily post - at least so far as I have seen - The day was lovely but uncomfortably warm - about 5 1/2 pm a very heavy storm passed to the eastward of us. Evidently hail - the unclear inch a sharp blow which lasted more than half an hour - after which

patience & got nothing in return - Then we got back we found that the men had made a unclear of Musquite bay & taken some 40 suckers, 18 at one hawl - among them a red sucker, with a long nose - mouth far under it & very fine scales - I have never seen it before. Orders to move tomorrow at 6. So as usual -

junction - There are a great many suckers, some channel on Lady Cali & some which fish called hickory shad in N.C? & herring in some other parts. There are also a few dace I fished very faithfully & used all my shell and I fear not a few bad hours? - but got only 1 cat 6 suckers & 3 dace. Foot was worse off for he displayed unexampled?

of the size of hazelnuts - The streams on that side were tremendously swollen - making some of our crossings difficult - & changing the pure sweet water of our mountain creek to a dirty white alkaline compound - The fish would not bite - We came down stream striking the main creek or river about a mile below the junction. It turns a little west of N. recurring? three tributary from the west. The

Wednesday Sep 15 -75
Broke camp 6.30 am Had some trouble crossing creek, so did not get fairly stretched out till 7am - passed over a portion of ground visited by the storm of yesterday afternoon - Though after 8 am the hail yet covered the ground in some places to the depth of several inches - & many of the stones were

way the Belle Fourche or not - There are good reasons on both sides - but there is no use speculating when we will know of a surety tomorrow - Got 3 grouse all I saw & one cat. all that bit. it is a miserable country for game. We are quite out of the Hills & on the plain - I can hardly unclear it - & look back on the black mass with longing unclear Distance about 13 miles - good camp - plenty of everything - lovely night -

third of which change the whole character & appearance of the stream - Down to this junction the stream is deep, rather narrow for the water carried very swift with frequent deep holes & low grassy banks - after striking the stream spoken of it spreads out with a wide channel is quick, shallow, nowhere more than 3 or 4 feet. Every body is exercised to know whether that tributary

Thursday Sepr 16, 1875
Broke camp 6.15 am. Had a poor day. Troubled with my old survey?. unclear unclear all day - & feel weak & good for nothing. When such circumstances everything goes wrong. I found a fine pack of sage grouse & got but one shot & one bird - The others disappeared in the most misterious way. Though

The valley passed down today - Mortons Creek is one of the very finest for a post I have seen in the Hills - splendid water & soil - excellent building stone - timber & limestone unclear & elegant hay bottoms - Water power sufficient for all sorts of mills -

bites, & succeeded in losing more fish that I even recollect on any other occasion - secured 4 cats (one very fine 3  pounder) 3 white fish - & a dace. Lost more than twice as many - Such is luck when it sets in bad, everything goes wrong - We have had no end of argument (& bettering among some) on the vexed question - "Is this the Belle Fourche or not? The question is not even yet definitely decided, for

completely marked down. This is the disadvantage of having no dog - Had a running? shot at a fine buck - think I hit but did not bag him - Found a pack of willow grouse in a thicket, got two snap shots, & no bird bagged - got to camp disgusted & tired & very weak in front & rear - Went to creek with my rod, & had lots of good

Friday Sep 17, 1875
Broke camp 6.20 am.  Dysentery a good deal better tho it seems to be beginning again tonight, just as I am going to bed - Nice pleasant day - Travelled down the Belle Fourche - decided at last to be such - crossed Custer trail about 3 miles from our last night camp. It is not within 4 miles of where he puts

there is still a chance that it comes in tomorrow - all I can say is that the maps are all wrong, not one giving even an idea of the portion? of the streams. Every one has his own idea & insists on beating that into the others - about 26 miles today. Good road. Camp Ford on high bank of stream Red water or Belle Fourche we don’t know which -

lot several times seeming at unclear distances & wounded a buck - The herd ran near the head of the Column & the Segt Major killed me. Joe's dog caught my wounded one buck but could not hold it & was beaten off - Returning to the bottom I saw another & getting behind a hill fired at about 600 yds - He was so far off that he did not run

it on his map - 
Bagged 3 willow grouse.
About 11 1/2 came into the valley to look for a camp - saw an antelope a long way off. Fired 3 shots at him each at a thousand or so yards & came so near him each time that it was a marvel how I missed him. He soon joined 3 others. I fired at the

very large white fish  - I have always had a preference against this fish though he bites well. We had them for dinner & they were delicious - I was too weak from yesterdays trottings to work much. Came back early & took a good nap - River turns much to the south from here. Expect to reach our supply camp tomorrow, when we will lay for a day or two - to bed early-

away. Though the bullet once covered him with dust. On the 3d shot he fell with a broken back from a ricochette shot - The longest successful shot made on the trip. Marched 12 miles - went fishing after getting into camp, but was not very successful. The river is wide & shallow & stands in giant pools. The fish are too much diffused - Took 4

animal & my first shot turned him out of the herd - Followed him a long distance, getting a shot once in a while, but unable to put any bullets where I wanted by the wind - Sent back to old Joe for for his dog but before the animal had bagged him - He had two shots directly behind the fore shoulder, but both unclear too low - one in the leg - one in the loin - one through the side & the back, 6 in all in his rump - yet before evening? the last he seemed

Saturday Sep 18, 1875
Troubled with my complaint all day - Broke camp 6.30. Had a pleasant march of about 12 miles to the junction of Bare Butte ck with the Belle Fourche. The day was very windy - Had a good shot at an antelope & missed him - three others ran from behind a hill & past me within 300 yds I selected a splendid

today, while I was after that confounded antelope. He lost me a fine opportunity, the best I have had for there were quite 50 birds - shall remain here until Jeremy & the other party arrives - Have a good camp, good grass & plenty of wood - Dr Sam caught some fish this afternoon -

able to run any distance I could not catch him with my horse, nor would he let me get near enough for a sun shot - I secured him at last by stopping - watching him until after going at least a mile he laid down. Even then I had to shoot running - was too sick & worn out to fish this afternoon - at night copied what I had written on Sage grouse - saw plenty of willow grouse

Good for a man with the b-y ache - Hope the writing will show no symptoms of the malady - Had my other tent pitched & a good fire made - It has been a raw [?] day except in afternoon, when the sun came out warm - Sent Joe out to look for water for my next march - found none, will have to change my direction, many fish caught today, among others an 8 pound cat on a small trout fly, by a teamster - Foote lent him the fly -

Sunday Sep 19, 75
Remained in camp today waiting for Jeremy & the other party - My bowels still trouble me greatly - If not better tomorrow must take some medicine a thing I hate to do - Spent the day writing on my book. Finished grouse - & started on the Turkey - nearly 25 pages today - very

Tuesday Sep 21, 1875
Diaroeha much better owing to the brandy & water drank last night with the Dr - still however have no confidence in my bowels - Determined to move, after consultation with Dr McG - Issued rations for his party to 6th Oct - For all others to 30th. Except Coales. Ordered his rations to 15th Oct to be weighed out & left here for him - gave order to move early tomorrow - Sat at night wrote letter to Jeremy, pitching into him amicably for

Monday Sep 20th 1875
Diaroeha very bad - unclear Wm. Gork? says let it alone - or take a dose of Castor oil - I let it alone - wrote considerable today - Dr McG & party came in late in afternoon. They have had a fine trip - Not out today at all. Dr Mc. & others at unclear at night - pleasant reunion - He is a really nice intelligent fellow - to bed late.

Wednesday Sep 22. 75
Equinox - but no storm. Broke camp 6.45 am - Travelled in a S.W. direction for the mountains - Crossed long slopes & some bad breaks, but the road was very good - struck for the point where Elk Ck comes out of the Hills. Tho' no one was certain we would find water there - was quite sick again, going out every few moments. I am getting very weak & my comfortable girth - has

not coming to him - Orders for Coales - am sorry to believe I have a thieving Com? Several articles were stolen last night. Shot a willow grouse this am in camp. It flew a hundred or so yards till a scamp of A Co bagged it & I have not been able to find this man - am out a grouse. If I catch any of the thieves I'll make it unclear for them. Dr McG goes to junction of N & S Cheyenne - marking? both rivers -

leaping in the Cactus where the dog could not run - He finally got away, for I was too weak to follow far -  When we got to the foot hill, I crossed lots of dry unclear & was beginning to despair when we came upon the true Elk, where I struck it a little jill, but rapidly increasing in volume - I went down about a mile & camped in a beautiful spot, plenty of delicious water, a boon from Heaven after the alkali of the Belle Fourche - good grass

shrunk to the circumference of an aldermans thumb. Had a shot at an antelope at about 300 yds - put my bullet into his chest - he was looking at me - & broke one of his shoulders - He went a little distance stopped & I thought I had him since but he saw us & put in his best unclear on 3 legs. I sent back for Joe & his dog, but the antelope was too smart

own protection - Foote, who saw the affair says the deer could not run at all. He trotted & hopped - & made scarcely any fight with the dogs - Indeed one caught & pulled him down but couldn't hold him. the others then came up & they held him till the men arrived - got to the camping place & sent back to direct the train while waiting a grouse started I went after him & got up a pack - bagged 3 & left the others on a unclear side unclear but where in my weakened condition I could not go

& fine oak timber for fuel - dry at that - we made a good long march. 22 miles, but we were all glad to get off at that with so fine a camp - a Black Tail buck jumped up by the train today, but was so fat that he could not run & was pulled down by the train dogs - "unclear of low degree" - The first time I have ever known of a wild animal getting too fat for its

Thursday Sep 23. 75
Broke camp 7. am Directed the wagons to follow Custer trail to where it came out of the mountain went up the creek & got into the valley between the Mts & foot hills - very hot day. Marched all day along the foot of the Mts - occasionally going up a canon - but saw nothing except 4 antelopes at a long distance off - Left Custer & struck off for

when the train got in I took my fishing rod & in a short time took 36 dace - some of them quite half a pound but the majority about 6 inches long - could not go far or work much - & cam back as soon as my tents was ready. The day has been excessively hot. Had a pleasant evening. No trouble with bowels & have fairly unclear in water drinking - satisfying a 7 days unclear - To bed 9 pm

Friday Sep 24, 1875
gave all final directions took an escort of 6 men 2 wagons & my ambulance & started - I got off at 9 am - Joe & the wagons half an hour later - Foote & I struck across country - The ground is very broken, much cut up by canons? - we hunted faithfully for four or five miles, without seeing anything - I then saw 2 deer & followed them off to the eastward?

Rapid - at 2 pm struck a most lovely spring & went into camp - Call it camp Warren may remain here a week that is the troops may. I go tomorrow with Foote into the Hills for a hunt - March today 17 miles & not hard except from heat - Had pleasant evening, several officers being around my camp fire - gave orders for my unclear tomorrow. Leave Fred as he is tired of hunting - went to bed rather late -

within? a short time after Crossing this I struck a stream of running water - Knew it must be Carnelco? followed it down & in less than half a mile came to Custers trail & the point designated for camp tonight - went down stream to see the unclear - got a long shot at another deer but the thicket was so dense I could not hit him - Joe & the wagons were not up & Foote supposed lost

Foote bring them a few hundred yards to my left - Failing to find them I went on a little way & stopped & stopped & waited for Foote - but finally concluded he was still on my left - crossed a nasty? canon - killing a deer on the way. I doubt if I had crossed it so easily but that I came upon a large old Indian trail -

Took the suckers with fresh venison as bait - Dr Lane a few days ago took a sucker with a bit of beefsteak - The suckers in Belle Fourche are not good - soft & tasteless. This tonight was splendid the real Rapid sucker - while I was fishing Foote ran? up - Not finding the trail by which I crossed he had been unable to cross the big canon & finally became alarmed lest

came back. Had the horses unsaddled & leaving the two orderlies with them went on foot up the creek.
Deer & elk sign plenty but not one animal did I see unclear than a squirrel Came back disgusted about 4 pm to find camp pitched got my fishing rod & went to work - Took a fine 2 lb sucker & 41 dace out of one hole -

Saturday Sep 25. 75
Started out a little after 6 am. leaving old Joe & Sergt Molloy to move camp - Took pack mule with me. Went up the little creek near the mouth of which we camped & which I supposed to be Carnelco? - about 2 miles from camp Locke one of the orderlies told me he saw a black tailed deer in a thicket of unclear unclear

he might not get into camp - went back nearly to our permanent camp & took the wagon trail - He travelled at least 20 miles more than there was any necessity of - got no game - His orderly killed a deer - & one of the guard got another so we have plenty to eat - To bed about 9 pm - Diaroeha all gone - Feel first rate -

of him - I took the chance but failed. He went off - I went as fast as possible to the top of the ridge, but though I could then see for a thousand yards all were gone, & I could hear the Buck unclear on an adjacent hill - Just then 3 deer attempted to pass me - In 3 shots all went down & another presenting himself opportunely I knocked him also. The ground was bad

while I was trying to see it, a few of the elk started out & went at speed to the top of the ridge, so managing the flight that I could not even get a running shot. Some of them stopped on top of the ridge - & one enormous buck stood broadside but nearly 400 yds off & so covered by timber & hemmed in by then that I could only see about 6 inches

It fell & rolled down the hill - yet when I came to look for the ded, I found the first, & one which I did not shoot at, while the one with 2 bullets through it got away - This is the second time on this trip that I have killed a second deer with a bullet that passed through a first - One of my 3 black unclear at camp Terry was killed so followed up the stream

thickets rocks & fallen timber so that I only bagged 3 of them - The other was the first one shot & I was so blown getting up the hill that I put the unclear too far back - I shot & killed another & my wounded one stopped about 150 yds off & the 3rd ran up along side of it - I fired at the one already wounded

canon to a beautiful running stream - Followed this up for 4 or 5 miles, expecting constantly to come into Egan's trail - & to my surprise & my great disgust I at last emerged from the box canon, (from which I could not get before) to find my self on my own road from Creek to Terry & only 5 miles from Camp Crook. I was thoroughly disgusted for it was now 12 m & I was at least 15 miles

or ravine, for it becomes perfectly dry. Til? finding it bore too much to the South I took up a right hand branch crossed some open park country & came to some deep unclear which I did not doubt led directly into Box Elder - while hunting a way to get down, I found the old Indian trail & followed it down a tremendous

but I thought Egan's a little nearer - at least it would put me in rear of & on the trail of my party while by the other I might miss camp if delayed until dark - Took Egan's Just at my old hunting camp saw 2 deer coming to water, crept down on them through the willows & bagged both - Egan's trail is much better than I thought it was - about a mile & a half from

from where I had directed the Comd to camp - There was no time or use to worry so I took Egan's false trail to near his first camp near which I killed a nice buck - Then struck across country for the camp. When I took Genl Crook hunting - Then the question was whether to follow Egan's or Curtin's? trails - Both were bad

After a unclear of at least 30 miles to make 12 - during which I have been forced by stress of course to travel at every point of the compass - I forgot to say that in the box canon, finding no signs of unclear game, I shot the head off a grouse - am satisfied with my day tho I lost the elk & made a great circuit

Box Elder on the unclear and in the small pine came onto 2 bucks & bagged one, struck Box Elder at last & the trail of my party - Followed it to camp, saying bad words against old Joe for persuading me to come here, & giving thanks that I had daylight to travel in, or I would have had to stay out - got into camp about 5 pm.

Sunday Sep 26.75
One of my unlucky days started out about 7 am sent the Sergt & party back to Box Elder - took Curtin trail westward. It is as crooked as a rams horn - saw nothing till we got near Beaver Dam Ck - when I shot at a deer not more than 75 yds off & missed it clear - at least I did not get the deer & saw

quite unnecessarily if I could have got out of that miserable canon. Yet 7 deer & a grouse is not a bad days bag - It was a tiresome but delightful day - Had a pleasant evening with Foote & old Joe - neither of whom killed anything - went to bed about the usual hour.

I then started down the canon of Beaver dam which soon ran into Box Elder, & a more infernal canon I never saw, rocks, thickets, beaver dams, sand, fallen trees Every obstacle that could be put in the way & yet not make it impassable after then hours of dusty? work & a bounty of bad words. I got to camp too tired & worn out even to go fishing which

no blood - shortly after I had a splendid shot at a deer n a Beaver dam & bagged it - Foote was in my way, as he will push ahead, yet can never kill anything himself. Finally sent him off towards camp, & worked hard for an hour or two without getting a shot though I saw 2 more deer together

unclear one travels miles for every deer he sees - & the travelling is abominable. Hurt my horses back today - Express from Hawley - Coales is in with part of his Compy - will send him on to Spotted Tail - Letter from Fred in fine spirits -

I had relied on to unclear my afternoon - I am more tired out than I was yesterday, though the actual distance travelled is not half so much - Lovely camp - Had a short nap, which did not suffice - am sick of this kind of hunting & gave orders to go in tomorrow - There is no game to be found.

work hard - got into camp 12.30 - traveled about 15 miles - by the trail - The wagons got in about 3 pm - found the guards not vigilant & pitched into several captains - gave orders for Coales to leave in the morning for Camp Sheridan - wrote to Chambers begging him to send out my com at all hazzards - Found Fred & all well - Relieved

Monday Sep 27, 75
started at 6.25 am going directly down Box Elder by the road - Did not take the trouble to hunt but killed a fine buck before I got to the ISl? Camp - seperated there & hunted a little buck though I saw lots of deer way too eager to get in to

I am sorry now that I did not make my hunting camp at my first camp out - There was a great deal of game about there & we would have done better - we went through the game - then was nothing far up in the Hills - went to bed late for camp -

all the men of Coales Compy except Serg Davis - wrote to Father & Mother -  very hot in the valley today after coming off the mountain - Jeremy is said to want to stay out till 1st Novr - Dont see it - Got unclear unclear bill - & made out all the men bills - 87 1/- cts per day for each little enough -

Wednesday Sep 29, 75
Repetition of yesterday - remained in camp all day.  But spent nearly the whole time writing - gave orders about issues tomorrow - wrote until my candles burned out - & went to bed. Storm came up in night -  -
Very hot day & also quite warm at night -

Tuesday Sep 28, 75
Very tired & lazy, tho got Coales off - in fair time & with instructions to go through Spotted Tail in 5 days if possible. Did little of anything except sleep & rest - wrote a little at night to bed early - very hot day - Dr Sam went with Coales -

12 m. & taking my tablets commenced writing - or rather continued - for I had been at it all morning. By 8 at night I had gotten through with all that part of my book devoted to hunting - have arranged it to suit me & I may say that my book is finished - Of course I shall have to go over it all this winter at Omaha revise correct punctuation & prepare it for the press - I have 340 pages

Thursday Sep 30. 75
Woke up this am with the wind howling & the rain pattering on my tent - Thought of Coales & his passage of the bad lands today - By 9 felt the rain had eased but the wind blew with great violence & the day has been cold & most uncomfortable. I went to bed about

Friday Oct 1, 1875
Broke camp 7 am.
Follow the trail of Coales Comd down the Rapid which is a beautiful stream though after getting 6 or 8 miles from the Hills it loses its purity & rapidity & becomes a murky & discolored, tho the water is good & though not a slow stream anywhere so far - it has long reaches of comparatively still water separate from each other by rapids

of unclear on hunting, which makes all together about 1100 pages - about dark the wind went down & we have a clear night, but cold, & will be colder, & the geese & cranes are going over constantly - bound south - came near having a serious fire today but finally got it out - Order to start early tomorrow - To bed 9 pm

600 & 1000 yds shot at antelope but got none - When we got into camp, Foote, Dr & I went fishing - I got a very good lot - (see unclear) - It has been a most perfect day, just cool enough, yet bright & beautiful. Every one was delighted - Marched 19 miles. Road excellent - not a particle of work for the Pioneers all day - nice camp on a spring of fine water near Rapid - good water & grass plenty & unclear - Dr & I filled cartridges at night & we all had a good time around my camp fire To bed 9.30 pm

The bed of the Creek is here filled with grass, & it becomes a fine feeding ground for ducks & geese - I saw great numbers today - but after shooting some, I would lose so much time getting there that the unclear would get ahead & unclear all the game? - Oh, if I only had a good dog - unclear - never to go on such an expedition without one or more - I bagged 17 ducks & 3 grouse. Had several

trail, found the Comd had not yet passed, said some bad words & when the Com? did arrive I let them know forcibly - that the march would have to be made if it took till dark - It was then 12? m & they had made 5 miles a mile an hour - made Foot stay with it - Fortunately there was but one more bad crossing & by a little after 4 pm all had arrived at the

Saturday Oct 2nd, 75
Broke camp 7.00 am Followed Coales Trail which still led down the creek - The crossings were bad Foote went ahead & did not watch the Pioneers. I went duck hunting & finding none went out on the prairie after antelope. Found & bagged a big buck, & when I returned to

or give me any satisfaction whatever - He sys he dont know, he must go where the work takes him - & stay as long as he thinks necessary. He places me in a very delicate & difficult situation. I am sent on this expedition to escort him & his party. I suppose I might claim that we have finished the work for which the expedition was organized viz the Survey of the Black Hills -

Cheyenne river - Found Jeremy. Dr McGillicuddy & all waiting for su the first time J. has been on time - He is however in a refractory mood & is determined not to go in - I tried to get him to go over to White river with me where he could get grains but he will? not go - unclear with he tell me where he is going how long he is to be gone

supply train was to meet us - & absolutely requisite to enable me to make requisition for supplies - He then detailed his projected route - (which by the by he has not stuck to) & told me that he wanted to get back to Ft Laramie by the 15th Oct - I made requisition for supplies, rations &c to 15 Oct - & when those had been delivered to me, I relieved the  unclear Col. which had been escorting my supply trains & sent them with all

& that I have therefore nothing to do but return to my legitimate duties. unclear this, however, I have a much stronger reason for going in - Before the last train was sent in for supplies I sent for Mr J. and asked him to detail to me his plans, where he wants to go, & how long to stay out - This was necessary to enable me to give proper orders as to where  the

scandal & widen the breach between the Interior & War Depts - He would understandably report me for hindering the completion of his work - & in defense, I would be obliged to show his indecisive vasallating character - & tell the facts of the case - 2d. - To send in to Camp Sheridan for supplies - Should I do this I risk the loss of men & animals in storms which may now be expected - Besides which Mr Jeremy

extra wagons & surplus of every kind back to their post - Now on this 2d Oct: he tells me that his work is not done, & that he must remain with an indefinite time beyond that fixed & provided for - Three courses are open to me - 1st. To force him in, by refusing him an escort, or pack mules - . This would cause ill feeling - & probably a

quarrel (which is not the case) I appear to be deserting him which I am not, for he acts as though he wanted me to go & leave him to himself - and this is I believe the true reason of his action - He hopes to make some extraordinary discoveries in the bone? unclear - He wants to keep these to himself & on them to base a chance of another exposition. He knows that he cannot hope to have

will give me no information or data on which to base acquisitions - I have no train to send in & no provision has been made for supplying me from that post -
3rd - To leave him to go his own way & to go in to Ft Laramie at the appointed time whether he comes or not -  This will look badly, & as if we had had a

when I ask him a question evades it by a story of numbers of antelope - or how scared the Indians were  - &c - He has got 3 wagons & an escort froma  company of 12 men stationed this winter at Red cloud - This escort is rationed to 15th - I have finally determined to go on as per programme - leaving him to himself as he evidently wishes  - I shall direct the Sergt in chg of his unclear to be at his post, camp

the secret kept if a dozer? or more intelligent officers pass over the same ground with him - & his object is now to get rid of us - He is not an imbecile by any means, & must have some plan. If he has, he unclear wanted me with him, he could give me some data on which I could make acquisitions - He will not tell me any thing, avoids the subject

of my seeking or making. I am doing the best I can so far as my unclear goes - & if any mishap occurs I shall not be able to blame myself. tho' I may be blamed by others - 
If Mr Newton or Dr McG were the head of the scientific exp - nothing of this kind would have occurred - struck the bad lands about 12 miles from here on Rapid - The creek is still rapid & there are no beaver dams today

Sheridan, on 15th - He, Jeremy, can take care of himself & in this country at this time & season he is in no danger - though he may lose some stock, which will be bad for me - This is really the only course that seems to be open to me. I am truly sorry that this so harmonious & successful expedition should have had this faux pas at the end of it - but it is not

Sunday, Oct 30, 75
Broke camp 8 am the crossing of creek having to be risked before we could start - Marched up the S Cheyenne, crossed spring Ck which comes apparently directly from the south, turns sharp to the east at only 3/4 of a mile & forms the Chn. about a mile & a half above crossing of Spg Ck Crossed the Cheyenne River The bed is here over 400 yds, though the thread of water running in it now is only

the water is not pure enough. The Creek is very boggy in some places - said to be no fish in it here - Didn't try - Don't believe it however - Rapid Ck valley very lovely - Distance today about 16 miles - Jeremy & all men to my tent at night - J. went away very happy - in avoiding explanation & getting rid of me. I go tomorrow - To bed later -

20 to 50 feet according to depth & rapidity. The stream does not now carry as much water as the Rapid brings to it. The road is very good except in the sandy bed & bottom of the river. Went up stream about 2 miles above crossing, & waited for return of the Sergt Major whom I had sent early this morning to ascertain the truth of reports made to me by Mr Jeremy, that there was plenty of wood & water in a canon about

most sanguine unclear can see wood & water in a dry desert of the Bad Lands - & see it so plainly as to report it officially - Had I had more confidence in him I might have got into a serious difficulty with my whole comy but I had so little confidence that last night when he told me I sent for Sergt McClellan & gave him orders to go out this morning & see if Jeremy's reports were true - This I did in Jeremy's presence & he must have felt

raw & uncomfortable. The clouds were heavy & threatening & occasionally there were little spits of rain or rather mist. Soon after I turned into Camp the clouds cleared away , the sun came out, & tonight is as clear as a bell - & there is every assurance of a cool but lovely day tomorrow - gave orders for a very early start - Had a pleasant evening. Took a nap in afternoon - To bed about 9 pm.

The general bottom of the bowl is level but scattered though it are hills & mounds of all shapes & sizes - cut into inconceivable designs by water - Castles & towers, domes & pinnacles obelisks monuments. The 5th avenue palace & the Indian teepe are here side by side, & all the varied forms are fluted & unclear by water & painted in various

beds of lakes - a vast quantity of sediment has been brought down the streams & deposited in the bottoms of these lakes - This sediment is consisted? of mud clay & various alkalies all these deposits was finally lifted from the water & exposed to the action of rain - The peculiarity of this soil is that it does not all equally resist or yield to the action of the water - some of the ingredients dissolve readily

this process, while the surface is yet only cut by narrow but deep channel, or while the amount of material to be washed away is yet considerable, these bad lands are many times absolutely impassible for wagons - When the water has worn away the projections? which intervened between the channels & the whole area has become practically a desert plain the travelling is not deficient

comparative plain, where much the larger portion of the peculiar deposit had been washed away - Through this we made our way with some difficulty - for some miles, when to the delight of every one we struck a great Indian teepe trail & soon after a wagon road (whose we do not know) along which we unclear merrily & comfortably - at the southern boundary

very worst & most alkaline water - The camp is poor tolerable grass, very little wood, tho' enough & abominable water - Fortunately we still have enough for ourselves & men brought from Francis? spring - but the animals must be disgusted - We are all very thankful that the much dreaded passage of the bad lands has been effected safely & with a

the bone? pilos?, as these great mounds in the bad lands are called. Found thousands of fossils but principally turtles of huge size, some in a fair state of preservation. Many bones of animals are among them, but generally we foudn only fragments, too small for us ignorant people to to tell what they were. Fred loaded himself with a unclear unclear of specimens. Orall? made a dry camp

Thursday Oct 5, 1875
Raining again when I woke up but we pulled out at 8am. We went diagonally away from the river & in a little while I noticed that all the little gulches in which the fallen rain was runningm went away from the river - This puzzled me decidedly - after two or three miles seeing no sign of the

came upon a large Camp of Indians - I did not go down to it, as I could not talk to them & knew they would be begging for every thing - a great many came out of their lodges & looked at us, & finally the Chief & a few of his orderlies came galloping up - Fortunately Wm. Jaquette & Dr Lawson were ahead. The Chief

Big Chief - I kept away & after following us for some miles, they departed in sorrow. Casting longing looks at the beaver? - They belong to Ft Sully & are on their road home from the Council - kept up the White for some 8 miles further, & went into camp in a lovely spot. Wood, water & grass all excellent - shot 4 ducks just after getting to camp & caught

a pleasant litter? & such me some papers - The weather cleared off nicely about 3 pm, but at this time 10 pm it is raining again a little - We are on the real White River now, about 40 miles from Spotted Tail - It is a nice stream, bed of about 100 feet - about 500 inches of water - pretty swift - Beautiful bottoms  - wide, fine grassed & well timbered -

unclear, & we had to water our stock with buckets - excellent camp otherwise . Tried fishing & had the best success I've had on the trip - In little over an hour took 3 cats of 3 lbs to 3 1/2 lbs. 3 large white fish - 7 or 8 smaller cats, & a dozen chubs - over  20 lbs fish - about 8 miles from camp we were over -

Thursday Oct 7, 1875
Broke camp 6.45 am. Marched up the White River by a good road for 14 miles to the old unclear - Then up the Beaver 7 miles to camp Sheridan - arrived at the latter post 2.15 pm. Chambers made me go to his house Frid

came away unclear Got hay & wood from Chambers, in return gave him 3 wagons to bring his family & goods to Ft Laramie. Country very broken & roads difficult - Dr Jaquette spent evening with me. Got to bed late - played 3 games of billiards with Chambers & beat him tho could not play well.

no need of a gun either for sport or protection - I get more tired in ten miles of such travelling than in a jaunt of 40 miles were game & variety attracts one - Got into camp about 2.30 pm on a small brook - Took my fishing rod & went after anything I could get - To my very great astonishment the dace were most plentiful

some of them would weigh quite half a pound - & in all the trip, I have seen no such dace fishing - I could have got any number more but quit on 150 - thinking that number enough - very good camp - grass not first rate - wood not very plentiful - but still enough of unclear - To bed 9 pm - No mail yesterday & ration made? today -

arrived at camp Robinson about 1 pm. I have heard a good deal about the beauty & desirability of this post but dont want any in mine? Capt Jordan comdg officer very polite - went into camp half a mile from the post. Miserable camp - water bad filled with dead animals refuse of Indian camps &c - no wood & no grass - got wood & grain from the post but no hay -

Sunday Oct 10th 1875
Broke camp 6.40 am Road led directly up river crossing frequently. The banks are very high & steep & the road one of the crookedest & up & down I have ever seen - It is however tho hard on animals a very fair road - Came up 12 miles found a place where grass is pretty fair

Eleven head of our cattle missing this morning, made a row, sent the herders out with threats to charge all the lost animals to them. Result all the cattle up this evening except one & that heard from - Parted with Capt Russile? 3rd Cav & Compy this morning. He has been with me for the whole expedition & is an excellent officer

Monday Oct 11, 1875
Broke camp 6.40 am continued up White River  by a much better road for five miles - then on to the divide & by a gradual dissent to the Niobrara. The days march was only about 16 miles, though we expected at least 21 - & we were in before 12 m - Niobrara a nice stream 10ft wide by 6 in. deep

I took 1 sucker & 105 dace from one single hole unclear once 10 feet square, & 8? feet deep - Some of the dace very large - a foot long & all much larger than the average - got tired & came in after taking 112 - Took a nap - Jeremy, Dr McG & Newton over to see me tonight - Had a pleasant evening, gave my paper on formation

Tuesday Oct 12, 1875
Broke camp 6.40 am Left the Niobrara at once & marched south west over a long succession of rolling prairie - in some places very sandy - Reached the Rawhide? at 12.50 pm distance 23 miles - Major got in at 3 pm, which was doing wonderfully considering the road & the distance - tried fishing but the fish are scarce

Wednesday Oct 13, 1875
Broke camp 6.45 am Marched over long slopes & on the same road on which we went out; Our trail that night connecting at the crossing of Rawhide? with the trail made by us on the 26th day of May - one hundred & forty days ago - What a long succession of pleasurable incidents

who appeared delighted to see me. Mason & wife arrived while I was in Bradley house - was introduced to Genl Brackett? - Saw many of the officers - Burt Munson? Devin &c - spent an hour in the Billiard room of course by which time the dust was blowing so thick that one could not see across the post - Went to telegraph office - Sent two messages to Genl Crook - one announcing my arrival & the second

Thursday Oct 14, 1875
Up about 7 this am after breakfast went up to see Genl Bradley - stopped unclear arriving?
Just got every thing turned over - paper not made out yet - Hope to be through tomorrow - played billiards called on Mrs Beech? & Mrs Mix & dined

would not take any thing - said I had more than paid a dozen such bills by my kindness to his people - Came back to camp about 8 pm  got tired of the pitch playing lot of tokens? in the billiard room - a very big Court is in session with plenty of rank - Chambers arrived today

Old Joe desperately drunk in a tent not far off, making night hideous - Dont like to be hard on him - as he is really a valuable man - Want to get off on Saturday & am urging everything to that end - Front? is extra good & works like a horse lame as he is - Platte & Laramie rivers both very low -

Heavy loafing for an hour or two - Dined with Genl Bradley 4 pm - paid Hubert & Mac. after dinner also 2 dols for washing - went to hop.  danced only once with Miss Hyatt or Hyette or something - Played billiards - got beat discounting king - gave him some good advice at parting. Went with the Mixes to their house & took a parting drink late

Saturday Oct 16, 75
up at 7 1/2. Breakfast at 8. Made a row about the ambulance provided for me, which was abominable & unfit got another & a good one - Started 9.30 am after bidding goodby to all. Genl Bradley & family all

Sunday Oct 17, 75
Got off 7.30 am later than we wished - arrived at Fagan's 25 miles 12.30. Mules fed & watered. Started again 2 pm arrived at Cheyenne 7 pm Road very fine - Total dist Today 52 miles - Excellent supper & unclear rooms at the R.R House - Jones' - To bed at 10 pm - old Beauvais & the Indian party with us last night & tonight -

Tuesday Oct 19 - 75
Arrived safe & sound. Rice met me at Depot everything all right - a splendid wind up to a splendid trip -

Back cover
Label: The Office Scratch Book
